issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: Signifies completion of tasks, info requests, etc.
resolution.name: Completed

fields.summary: Use more XHR calls to perform functions that don't require page change

status.description: This issue has been validated/reproduced, but has not been prioritized yet.
status.name: Confirmed

issuetype.description: A user story. Created by JIRA Software - do not edit or delete.
issuetype.name: Story

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Navigate to Stacks landing page
2. Create stack (if not already created)
3. Delete stack 

What should happen: The stack should be deleted and the landing page should refresh to show that the stack is no longer there.
What actually happens: The stack gets deleted but the landing page never refreshes so it looks like the deleted stack is still there.

If you refresh the stacks landing page manually, the deleted stack gets removed.
fields.summary: Stacks landing page does not refresh after deleting stack

comments.body: It's a race condition. I actually see the landing page refreshed soon after, but it was too soon to see the stack being deleted. Now, if the stack was in "delete-in-progress" state, then, we'd auto-refresh till it is actually deleted, but we don't catch it in a transitional state. I can make a movie if you like, but I've just been deleting some old stacks and can demonstrate this behavior over and over. In fact, I refreshed just now after a delete and got that transitional state, which caused the page to refresh periodically till it was done deleting.

I think the only thing we can do besides tell the back end "be more consistent" (which is just not the way cloud is built), is to add a wait on the refresh after delete. A small wait will likely be helpful, so we need to figure out what will be short enough to seem related to the delete (and not a random refresh), but long enough to catch the stack in the delete-in-progress state.
Adding a one-second delay should fix this.

Looking at this, the delete is handled as form submission and the landing page is loaded afterwards, not knowing it came from a delete operation. It isn't easy to say "only delay the refresh if we came from a delete operation". Nothing's impossible, but there isn't a very clean/easy solution unless we started doing delete with an XHR w/o a total page reload. cc: [~jloza]
XHR is fine by me. Shouldn't affect externally visible behavior except for the positive of having the deleted stack removed.
No externally visible changes, so no need for UX review. Passing on for code review.
[~dkavanagh]: Couldn't we have replaced the code in PR 1459 with a one-line time.sleep(1) in the stacks_delete view?

[~dkavanagh]: I've confirmed adding a one-second time.sleep call fixes this issue with far less code churn.  Feel free to look at the GUI-1801-patch branch (the relevant commit is at http://git.io/vqF9y) to confirm.

I get what you're saying. I've seen sleeps like this elsewhere in the code. Definitely far simpler. User gets feedback a second later, but maybe not a big deal. I'd like to see us do more with XHR calls vs form submits that cause a page reload when one really isn't necessary. We could argue that the code changed here is a bit more than we'd want (or not) in this stage of the release. In this case, it only affects a single function on a single landing page, so it's pretty isolated. I think the UX of what I did is preferable, so let's talk about this as a group?

The deletion shows up properly now without refresh.
{code}
